frqParts.text: Write your answers in the spaces provided. Refer to the figure or diagram to answer the question. Where explanation or discussion is required, support your answers with relevant information and/or specific examples. The graph shows measurements of atmospheric levels of carbon dioxide (<math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>) at Mauna Loa Observatory, Hawaii, and the measurements of <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> levels in the ocean nearby at Station ALOHA. Measurements of <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> began in 1992. (a) Use the graph above to answer the following questions. (i) Determine the concentration of <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> (in <math alttext="p p m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ppm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) recorded at Mauna Loa in 2005. (ii) Determine the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> recorded at Station ALOHA in 2005.

(b) Changes in atmospheric carbon dioxide affect Earth’s oceans.(i) Predict the effect of increased concentration of atmospheric <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> on the concentration of <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in the ocean.(ii) Based on the data, identify the relationship between the concentration of atmospheric <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of ocean water.(iii) Provide the complete chemical equation that represents the reaction between oceanic carbon dioxide (<math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>) and water (<math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>).(iv) Identify the specific environmental problem that directly results from the decrease in <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of Earth’s oceans.

(c) Changes in <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the world’s oceans pose a risk to many marine organisms.(i) Explain why certain organisms, in particular those with calcium carbonate shells or exoskeletons, are threatened by the decreasing <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> levels measured in seawater.(ii) Other than threats posed by decreasing <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, identify an additional anthropogenic threat to the world’s coral reef ecosystems and describe how the threat damages the coral reefs and coral reef ecosystems.
